properties.name: Virginia Shipbuilding Corporation
properties.park: Jones Point Park - George Washington Memorial Parkway
properties.description: On April 17, 1917, the United States Shipping Board created the Emergency Fleet Corporation. The Virginia Shipbuilding Corporation of Alexandria, VA took advantage of the lucrative contracts offered.

properties.name: The Bull Moose in Winter: Theodore Roosevelt and World War I
properties.description: During the war years, Theodore Roosevelt advocated for direct U.S. involvement. His sons and daughters all found important roles, and made great sacrifices for the cause.

properties.name: Tank Training at Camp Colt
properties.description: On the same field where Pickett's Charge occurred 50 years earlier, Dwight Eisenhower trained troops in the new art of tank tactics.

properties.name: The Art of Camouflage
properties.description: Camouflage was first developed in France in 1914 by artist Lucien-Victor Guirand de Scévola and others. n the United States, this development took place a few years later, using the talents of the artists of the Cornish Colony in Cornish, New Hampshire, at the site of the present-day Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site.

properties.name: National Woman's Party Protests
properties.description: “When men are denied justice, they go to war. This is our war, only we are fighting it with banners instead of guns.” -Alice Paul

properties.name: Bonus Expeditionary Forces March on Washington
properties.description: In the depths of the Great Depression, a dramatic showdown between jobless WWI veterans, lawmakers, the police, and the Army played out in Washington, DC.

properties.name: Franklin Delano Roosevelt - Assistant Secretary of the Navy
properties.description: From the start, FDR worked to prepare the navy for the coming war, and was troubled that others did not see it his way.
properties.park2: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site

properties.name: Charlestown Navy Yard
properties.description: Thousands of workers built, repaired, and refitted naval vessels,  and it was the assembly point for destroyers heading out to sea at the outbreak of war.

properties.name: Training for Trench Warfare
properties.description: The brutality of trench warfare in the Civil War was but a tiny preview of the horrors to come in World War I, just fifty years later.

properties.name: Coastal Defense: Fort Hancock during World War I
properties.description: When the US declared war on Germany in 1917, coastal fortifications like Fort Hancock quickly sprung into action to defend the nation against possible threats. The fort activated from a sleepy post to a center of wartime mobilization in a matter of months.

properties.name: The DH-4 Liberty Plane at War and in Peace
properties.description: The DH-4 Liberty plane, manufactured from Sitka spruce logged from the forests of the Pacific Northwest, played a significant role both in battle and after the war.

properties.name: Innovative Defenses at Fort Tilden and Rockaway Naval Air Station during WWI
properties.description: Part of a larger coastal defense system dating to the 18th century, Fort Tilden and Rockaway Naval Air Station helped protect the homeland during World War I against some of the most advanced weapons systems of the time.

properties.name: The Statue of Liberty in Recruitment and War Bonds Posters
properties.description: When the US entered into World War I, the government was faced with the dilemma of converting and funding a standing army to armed forces. The solution enacted were propaganda campaigns with intense recruiting and fundraising appeals that employed the Statue of Liberty as the symbol of American freedom. The Statue appeared in poster images with banner logos designed to appeal to the public’s sense of nationalism, competition, guilt, fear, revenge and social standing.

properties.name: Closing the Door on Immigration
properties.park: Ellis Island - Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument
properties.description: US participation in World War I fanned the flames of anti-immigrant sentiment, despite the fact that many immigrants served with distinction in the US military.

properties.park: Ellis Island - Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument
properties.name: Immigrants in the Military during WWI
properties.description: Many of the immigrants who entered the United States in the Ellis Island era found themselves serving in the military during the First World War.

properties.name: Immigration and the Great War
properties.park: Ellis Island - Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument
properties.description: During the decade leading up to the war, an average of 1 million immigrants per year arrived in the United States, with about three-quarters of them entering through the Ellis Island immigration station in New York Harbor. By 1918, a trickle of only 110,618 people were arriving in the United States.

properties.name: The War in Popular Music: Irving Berlin
properties.park: Ellis Island - Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument
properties.description: One of Ellis Island’s most famous immigrants provided the soundtrack to America’s participation in the First World War. Irving Berlin, a popular songwriter, produced patriotic popular music to inspire soldiers and to divert those who needed a break from wartime concerns.

properties.name: Departing and Arriving US Soldiers View the Statue of Liberty
properties.description: For some US soldiers shipping off overseas, the journey to the European battle fields began with departure from the port of Hoboken, New Jersey, into New York Harbor past the Statue of Liberty.

properties.name: Domestic Sabotage: The Explosion at Black Tom Island
properties.park: Ellis Island - Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument
properties.description: In the early morning hours of July 30, 1916, a munitions depot located on Black Tom Island, in Jersey City, NJ, was deliberately sabotaged to prevent supplies from being delivered to Britain and France during World War I. Although this is the closest some would come to combat during the war, the attack rattled at America’s golden door.
properties.park2: Ellis Island Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument

properties.name: Keweenaw Copper at War
properties.description: As World War I entered its second year, the American Institute of Metals trade journal blithely remarked that “[i]t is almost impossible to kill a man in an up-to-date and scientific way without using copper."
